The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline if the optimum growing temperature is exceeded. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 86% under 4 °C warming, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 20% increases to 20%. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant foods is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work highlights the importance of diet composition in understanding the ecology of large mammals.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely, with some businesses expecting to remain open for many months. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is a major unsolved problem in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the formation of the solar system. We determined the age of interstellar grains in the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the solar system ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system formed in a relatively short time after the formation of the first stars. This is in contrast to the idea that the solar system formed over a long period of time.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the substantia nigra, and the striatum. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. VX-765 was able to reduce truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this orphan disease. (Read more)

It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, allowing for the rapid and robust communication of information between the cells. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modelers. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a rich set of public health surveillance and auxiliary signals, all updated daily at a fine geographic resolution. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are designed to be useful for tracking the pandemic, augmenting traditional public health reporting, and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the API will be useful to researchers and practitioners in the public health community.

The gut microbiome is also highly diverse, and the composition of the microbiome can vary greatly between individuals. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We propose that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious individuals is a consequence of their reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens for social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a strategy to synthesize multifunctional structures with multiple material phases that can be digitally designed to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are then fabricated with different elastomers to realize the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional architectures with complex and programmable behaviors. The developed structures can be used in various applications, such as energy trapping, actuation, and sensing.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1, which is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is developmentally downregulated in fetal liver. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of the adult hemoglobin system and that this silencing can be reversed by IGF2BP1 overexpression. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a potential regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis in cancer cells. Finally, we show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment, especially in patients with cancer cells harboring mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easier to train and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known climatic event that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of autoimmunity is well established, but the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in adult mice remains to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of life, the type of autoimmunity, and the effector cells involved. (Show more)

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes encoding microbial enzymes to trace the evolution of beetle herbivory, revealing that the origin of specialized herbivores coincided with the first appearance of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. This suggests that the evolution of specialized herbivores was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

However, the mechanism by which APOE influences AD risk is not known. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 1,220 km, which is the fastest rotating object in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the Earth and other rocky planets. They also suggest that the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is not unique and may be applicable to other crystallization processes.

The brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels, was compared between marijuana abusers and controls. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and increases in brain reactivity to MP. In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), MP-induced reductions in DVs and BPND (reflecting DA increases) were inversely correlated with scores of negative emotionality, which were significantly higher for marijuana abusers than controls. In marijuana abusers, DA responses in ventral striatum were also inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the importance of the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation in understanding the addictive potential of marijuana.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, our understanding of how the human brain processes language is limited. Here, we show that artificial neural network models of language processing, trained on large datasets of speech, predict brain responses to sentences measured with fMRI and electrocorticography. The models’ neural fits and predictive ability are both higher when trained on more data, have higher accuracy on a language task, and generalize across datasets. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the next step is to understand how the brain’s predictive mechanisms are shaped by evolution. Such an understanding could help us understand how the brain processes language and other complex cognitive and social skills.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is not clear why DL works so well, and it is not clear how to prove that a given problem can be solved with a given accuracy using DL. We address these questions by introducing a classification theory of the conditions under which one can prove the existence of a stable neural network (NN) with a given accuracy. We prove that the number of layers needed to achieve a given accuracy is bounded by a polynomial in the logarithm of the accuracy. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and accurate. We believe that this theory will help to guide the development of DL and will lead to a deeper understanding of the limits of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published 45 years ago, which purported to show that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that the study’s design was flawed in multiple ways, and that its conclusion is therefore not supported by the evidence.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with the diffuse form of the disease known as lepromatous leprosy. The genomes of M. lepromatosis and M. leprae are similar in size and synteny, and have a similar number of protein-coding genes. However, M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae, and a Bayesian dating analysis suggests that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 13.9 Mya. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. However, it was only recently possible to compute the entanglement dynamics exactly for a paradigmatic model, the Heisenberg chain, and only for a very short time. This paper provides a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the natural limit to compare with thermodynamics. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics and its implications for the understanding of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems.

This study describes a vaccine candidate that is temperature sensitive, easy to manufacture, and can be administered as a single dose. This vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, resulting in a milder disease in hamsters, and is highly protective in hamsters. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of plague during this period. This is a significant finding, as it challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results suggest that the spread of plague in Europe was driven by human behavior, such as the movement of people and trade, rather than by the movement of rats. This has important implications for the control of plague in Europe, as well as for the spread of other diseases in human populations.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different species have different numbers of neurons. Here, we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuron numbers across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The HSP90 chaperone family is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including protein folding, protein degradation, and protein–protein interaction. The HSP90 family member TRAP1 is found predominantly in mitochondria, where it is involved in the regulation of apoptosis. Here we show that TRAP1 also regulates the metabolic state of cells, promoting an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the barbed end of the filament and severing it. However, the physiological relevance of this process is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF is able to sever filaments under tension, but not under compression. We also find that the mechanical torque that is induced by the filament network on ADF-bound filaments is critical to boost severing. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanism is likely to be relevant to other actin depolymerizing factors as well.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters because it is calorie-free. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake are unclear. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues, greater hunger, and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite and may promote feeding behavior. Understanding the effects of different caloric sweeteners on brain and behavioral responses may help elucidate the mechanisms of action of these sweeteners and inform future research and public health policy.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. They also suggest that the island was not a “garden of Eden” and that the human population was not already admixed when the first Malagasy arrived. Finally, they suggest that the island was colonized by multiple waves of people.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred across social networks, even when they are separated by space. We also show that people can experience positive emotions from observing others’ positive experiences, and negative emotions from observing others’ negative experiences. These results suggest that people are not just passive recipients of emotions, but that they can actively choose to experience positive or negative emotions. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a well-established feature of the transcriptome. In this study, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest impact on the decoding of mRNA codons by the ribosome. We find that the presence of Ψ can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to a codon, and can increase the rate of translation of an mRNA. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs can have a modest impact on the decoding of mRNA codons, and may have important implications for the regulation of gene expression. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater use of time. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and the findings are consistent over a 4-y period. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a cooler core temperature of the nose, but the molecular basis for this phenomenon has not been elucidated. We show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of rhinovirus temperature dependence and may have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and therapeutics. Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and respond accordingly. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, and involves the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. This finding demonstrates that P. aeruginosa uses pili as a sensor to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of this mechanosensory system will be important for developing new strategies to combat this pathogen. (Show more)

The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a major concern for the sustainability of aquatic ecosystems. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk they pose to the biological integrity of these ecosystems. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the risk of their adverse effects on aquatic biodiversity is high. The results suggest that the current regulatory framework for the use of pesticides in agriculture is not effective in protecting surface waters.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a comprehensive understanding of the ecology of the virus that causes it. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a major concern because of the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to the food system, water quality, and agriculture. This paper examines the problems associated with the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, the earliest events in AD pathogenesis are not well understood. Here, we demonstrate that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons. We show that neurons are the primary source of cytokines that trigger microglial activation, and that this neuron-derived inflammatory response precedes the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the earliest inflammatory event in AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of this species. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. We show that the frequency of chicken remains increases sharply during the Hellenistic period, and that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The best that can be done is to characterize the steps that the protein takes to reach the native state. This study characterizes the steps that the maltose binding protein takes to fold. The results show that the protein folds through distinct intermediates, and that the intermediates are important for the folding process. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, RppH, also removes the cap from stress-induced dinucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) capped RNAs. We show that RppH preferentially removes the cap from Np4-capped RNAs, and that this preference is due to the unusual manner in which Np4-capped RNAs bind to the active site of RppH, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. This shift in substrate specificity may have major implications for the ability of bacteria to rapidly degrade stress-induced RNAs. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore immune function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and the system’s activity or rate of change of state fluctuates about a reference value. SOC systems are often characterized by a power-law distribution of activity levels, and the activity of the system changes in response to external forcing or internal dynamics. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be tuned reversibly and continuously in six-dimensional strain space. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned to be similar to that of graphene, and that the bandgap of diamond can be tuned to be similar to that of a metal. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new route to control the properties of diamond.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of biofungicides. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the molecular mechanisms of action are not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides, and its activity is dependent on its ability to bind to the cell wall. These findings provide insights into the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of this peptide, which can be used to develop this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is the first report of the antifungal activity of a plant peptide against plant fungal pathogens. This work also highlights the potential of plant peptides as a new class of biofungicides. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for the adhesion of platelets to endothelial cells, but its function is also important in the control of bleeding. The A1 domain of VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and is thought to be regulated by the flow of blood. We show that force can regulate the binding of A1 and GPIbα to each other, and that this regulation is important for the function of VWF. This work provides a mechanism for the regulation of the function of VWF, and explains the effects of mutations in VWF. It also provides a mechanism for the effects of flow on the function of VWF. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database is publicly available and can be used to study the human virome in the future.

The aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. The HSRL is capable of providing high-resolution observations of aerosol and cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this technique to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present paleotemperature estimates for ancient organisms based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from their genomes. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by multiple mechanisms. The activation gate is the main ion-conducting pore of ion channels and is responsible for channel opening. The inactivation gate is the main ion-blocking selectivity filter of ion channels and is responsible for channel closing. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the human red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that this interaction leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine and therapy. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences is consistent with a model in which each word is merged with the preceding word to form a phrase. This merge operation is applied repeatedly to form a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our results suggest that the brain’s implementation of a left-corner parser is consistent with the linguistic theory of phrase structure.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates a wide range of processes, including cell fate determination, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled and the downstream scaffold Axin. We show here that the two forms of Axin are functionally redundant, but the two are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to fine-tune the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region. This circuit is critical for the LH-induced eating, as lesions of LH, peri-LH, or dopamine neurons block the effect. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity, a major public health concern.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This system could be used to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture, with the potential to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen to the plant, reducing the need for synthetic nitrogen fertilizers. This work also represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant, preventing interaction with nontarget plant species. This work could be extended to other nitrogen-fixing bacteria, such as cyanobacteria, to engineer the nitrogen cycle in aquatic ecosystems. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest cover at an alarming rate, and the causes of this loss are not well understood. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use, and the additional benefits of reducing other anthropogenic sources. We show that a phaseout of fossil fuels can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year worldwide, and that additional reductions of nonfossil anthropogenic sources can further reduce this to 2.2 million per year. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic warming, and that removing anthropogenic particles can reduce the global temperature rise by 0.51 °C. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries are still waiting for access to vaccines. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that contains a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This variant is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine, and we show that presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle further enhances immunogenicity. This engineered RBD variant could be included in a vaccine that is manufactured at large scale, potentially providing a needed vaccine intervention for many low- and middle-income countries. The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Finally, we show that the three ALKALs are able to activate human ALK/LTK family receptors in vitro. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. This study provides a link between the human ALKALs and the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This knowledge will be important for understanding the role of ALKALs in human disease. It will also be important for the development of zebrafish models for human ALKAL-associated diseases.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provides a unique opportunity to explore the evolution of this pathogen. Our results reveal a single lineage of Y. pestis that persisted over millennia without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its early evolution and ecology. They also highlight the importance of the flea vector in the spread of plague throughout Eurasia. This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. The recent pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of spillover of novel viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from a virus discovery project, we validated the risk assessment and ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from animals to humans.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important cue for pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying the evolution of color in nectar are not well understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, which is a hummingbird-visited species. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of color in nectar and the mechanisms underlying the convergence of this trait in two different vertebrate-pollinated species.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany, who lived mostly during the 6th century AD. The analysis of their genomes indicates that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly similar to modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are dependent on the host species. The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a cloud-based metagenomic next-generation sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to rapidly deploy public health response. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the lagging strand template being replicated in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in a processive manner, but the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is not very stable and dissociates rapidly from PCNA. This behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is a central problem in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically proximate to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods experience, on average, larger negative improvements. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 are identified. The results show that the immune system is suppressed, and the inflammatory storm is triggered, which may be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus is a leading cause of invasive fungal disease, and the development of antifungal resistance is a major concern. The ability of this fungus to sequester copper is of particular interest, as copper is an essential micronutrient and is a target for many antifungal drugs. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in A. fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide metabolite that has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance in woody plants to infer the evolutionary adaptations of trees to frost and forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

The generation of a pathogenic Th17 cell response is a hallmark of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here we show that the generation of pathogenic Th17 cells is contingent on the development of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These cells are themselves capable of generating a pathogenic Th17 response and are required for the development of colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. These results suggest that the generation of a pathogenic Th17 cell response is a two-step process, with the generation of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells being a critical step in the development of disease. This process may be amenable to therapeutic intervention.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different mutations causing the same disease. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. This method will also enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate motor neuron toxicity. This will greatly advance ALS research and ultimately lead to the development of effective treatments. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma to vertebrate hosts. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod vector to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the gut microbiota in pathogen transmission by arthropod vectors. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is a key step in the development of the modern avian bauplan. The discovery of a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, the clade Pygostylia, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail. The new taxon, Jinguofortis, is the second earliest diverging member of the Pygostylia and preserves a mosaic combination of plesiomorphic nonavian theropod features and more derived flight-related morphologies. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the Earth. This feedback is important because it is positive, meaning that increases in water vapor increase the amount of water vapor in the stratosphere, which in turn increases the amount of water vapor in the stratosphere. This positive feedback is not as strong as the negative feedbacks that are commonly thought to be important, but it is significant.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the occurrence of blue-green vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the mechanism is the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We also describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of blue-green vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a hallmark of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the proportion of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) in the tumor microenvironment. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α, which also induce the expression of NANOG, the master regulator of BCSCs. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the proportion of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, when parchment was so thin that it could be folded into a pocket. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which is defined by the onset of the global extinction. The age of the boundary is constrained by the age of a volcanic ash bed, which is the most common marker for the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of five ash beds, which are the most common markers for the extinction. The age model is consistent with the carbon cycle changes that occurred during the extinction. The age model is also consistent with the recovery of the biota, which occurred on a decamillenial to millennial timescale. The age model presented here is an important step in understanding the causes and consequences of the end-Permian extinction. (Show more)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the excessive immune response against the intestinal microbiota. The intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) are the first line of defense against the invading pathogens and maintain the homeostasis of the intestinal microbiota. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal homeostasis. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in circulating virus, and several studies have suggested that it is associated with increased infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spikes and show that the G614 mutant spike adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the ACE2 receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the G614 mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the development of chemical models. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the development of a chemical model based on pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer. This model could be used to predict the behavior of elements under pressure, and it could be used to explain the formation of unexpected compounds under pressure.
