Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the effects of this on the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which in turn can reduce the amount of carbon released to the atmosphere. This can offset some of the warming caused by climate change. However, the risk is that more extreme fires could occur in the future, which would negate the benefits of reduced fire activity.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbial communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is the cue that triggers the maturation of the symbiotic organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. This glycan is released by the host’s immune cells, which migrate into the symbiotic organ just before dusk, where they lyse and release the glycan. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, which is dependent on the catabolism of the glycan by the symbiont. This glycan-catabolizing activity is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. We propose that this glycan-catabolizing activity is a general mechanism used by animals to control the composition of their symbiotic microbial communities. This mechanism may be particularly important in the case of bioluminescent symbionts, which are often associated with the maturation of the symbiotic organ.

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent words. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease spread across Europe. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics. We find that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the disease was not permanently established in Europe, but rather that the spread of the disease was driven by climate-driven human migration. This study provides a new perspective on the spread of the plague, which is still relevant today, as the disease is currently spreading in the context of climate change.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting a large number of species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly through the population, leading to the rapid loss of many species. We show that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself, and that the disease is associated with the presence of the virus in the tissues of the affected animals. The virus is also present in the environment, suggesting that it can spread to other areas.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor, with a high mortality rate. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment strategy for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. They also suggest that the island is not a single population, but rather a mosaic of populations, which is a key factor for the uniqueness of the island. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete for the same resource, the encoded protein. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to control carbon utilization. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing information on crop status and condition to the government and the public. However, the information provided by these experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used for quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this information to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of leveraging the network of “people as sensors” to improve the accuracy and precision of agricultural monitoring and management.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, which reveal that soil respiration does not increase uniformly in response to warming across all biomes. Instead, soil respiration appears to follow a Gaussian response, increasing up to a threshold temperature, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This response is consistent across a range of biomes, and highlights the need for further research to understand the mechanisms behind this response.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of eukaryotes. It is characterized by the loss of photosynthesis and the acquisition of a new lifestyle, which is characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing the development of adaptation strategies. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic (made by humans) quasicrystal, trinitite, was created in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, in 1945. Here, we report the discovery of a new anthropogenic quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, in red trinitite, which was created in 1945. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, and the discovery of the Trinity test, are both indelibly etched in history.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” is the last step in the pathway and remains enigmatic. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of MS. In this study, we found that ASK1, a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, is highly expressed in microglia/macrophages and plays a critical role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the early stage of EAE, whereas deficiency in astrocytes ameliorated the later stage of EAE. ASK1 in microglia/macrophages activated astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation, suggesting a phase-specific role of ASK1 in the glial cell–microglia/macrophage interaction. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability that dry precipitation years are also warm has increased, and this increase is also attributable to human activities. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. (Show more)

This work represents the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of many cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the SO channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1, which result in spontaneous bleeding and miosis, respectively, in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be an important strategy for treating these diseases. The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged, which is thought to be an important factor in the maintenance of the bat–virus coevolutionary dynamics. However, the mechanisms underlying the immunologic privilege of bats remain largely unknown. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the activity of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of the potent lipid chemoattractant LTB4. We show that MTX facilitates viral infection by inhibiting the antiviral immune response of the host. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologic privilege of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) provides these units, but cancer cells have a unique metabolic vulnerability to SHMT inhibition. We have identified a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT, and have used this scaffold to identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that these inhibitors are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in the brains of patients with ALS suggests that the disease is associated with a progressive loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. We show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, but rather that they are a distinct set of proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. This suggests that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, allowing for the study of many-body physics in a controlled environment. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light from the atoms, allowing for the study of spontaneous emission in a controlled environment. The earliest known aquatic angiosperms are of great interest because they are the ancestors of many of the most diverse and ecologically important plants on Earth today. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has been hampered by the lack of a detailed description of the plant. Here, we present a detailed description of Montsechia, including its anatomy and reproduction. We also present a cladistic analysis of Montsechia and other early aquatic angiosperms. The results of this analysis suggest that aquatic angiosperms were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. This study also raises questions about the position of aquatic angiosperms in the angiosperm tree of life. (PsycINFO Database Record

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya, which is consistent with the spread of B19V in humans during the last ice age. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

The rate of global mean sea level rise is accelerating, and the acceleration is being driven by climate change. This acceleration is not due to human activities, but the acceleration is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a major public health concern, but the trends in pain over the life course are not well understood. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence increases with age for each successive birth cohort, and that the increase is greater for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern of working-class decline for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure of enzyme intermediates in situ and in atomic detail is a major goal of structural biology. Here, we demonstrate the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this intermediate, including the location of the water molecule that acts as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the catalytic residue, and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The results also highlight the importance of the active site environment in determining the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway. These results demonstrate the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of the continued development of animal models for emerging infectious diseases. (Simplified version available.)

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbial communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, which is required for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is synthesized by the host, and its provision to the symbionts is restricted to a single time of day. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to control the activities of their associated microbes.

This paper reports on a series of experiments that tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of American schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the function of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis, which is required for virus entry into cells. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may be relevant to the development of vaccines and antiviral agents. (Show more)

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of global disease burden. The food choices of the population have a major impact on these outcomes. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple intervention that can be implemented in a wide range of settings, from universities to hospitals to workplaces. The results suggest that this intervention could have a significant impact on the environment and population health.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also show that the surfaceome is sensitive to the oncogene, and that the glycoproteome is similarly sensitive to the oncogene. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that this paper will help to inform the public debate about the merits of vote-by-mail programs.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is particularly challenging because of the high rate of sequence change in the viral genome. The development of a therapeutic is also challenging because of the high rate of change in the viral protein, ORF8. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface that may be important for immune evasion. This structure will be useful for the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia and may provide a basis for the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a fundamental challenge in the analysis of complex datasets.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells remains a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is independent of the expression of hematopoietic transcription factors, and the ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. These findings provide a promising approach for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 as a transcription factor for the generation of ECs may be applicable to the generation of ECs for the regeneration of vascular networks in the liver and other organs. (Show more)

The orphan RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are involved in the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment cells. We show that the zebrafish genome encodes three augmentor ligands for Alk and Ltk, which are essential for the development of iridophores, the pigment cells that cover the body of adult zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for the study of the physiological function of orphan RTKs. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective

The influenza A virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that infects birds and mammals. It is responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Understanding the molecular details of the packaging process is essential for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions, which are the result of a series of pathological events. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is induced by disturbed flow, which promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but human-caused wildfires have become a significant problem in the United States. We show that human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire activity, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas where fuel moisture is higher, thereby helping to expand the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and neighborhoods that are physically proximate to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvements. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that our work will inspire future research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with a variety of severe complications, including microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome. The mechanisms of these complications are not well understood, but the recent outbreak has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algae, the zooxanthellae, which occurs during thermal stress. We show that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress is a key process in the breakdown of the symbiosis, and that this process is driven by altered nutrient cycling. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal tumor model leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of the intestinal barrier. We further show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the intestinal tumor microenvironment in the regulation of the intestinal microbiome and the intestinal barrier. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. The development of therapies that can improve the response to chemotherapy is needed. Here we show that the activation of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 enhances the response of breast cancer cells to chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to survive chemotherapy, and that this can be used to improve the efficacy of chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate, with some studies suggesting that the onset was delayed by several hundred years. We show that the onset of deglaciation was triggered by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and that this event is consistent with the timing of deglaciation. This study provides a new perspective on the timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in triggering the climate changes. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high levels of stress. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that these populations are disproportionately reliant on inland fisheries. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from the impacts of intensive fishing.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential range. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices.

The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the adult nervous system, but this capacity is lost in the mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling cascade, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult Drosophila and mammalian CNS. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite and is enhanced by activating calcium signaling. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for discovery of genes that mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. Moreover, our study unites disparate forms of neuronal outgrowth to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Finally, our study has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie the loss of regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. (Show more)

The process of DNA recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in all organisms. In eukaryotes, the process is highly variable, with some regions of the genome undergoing intense recombination, whereas others are largely devoid of it. The mechanisms that generate this variability are not well understood. Here, we present a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, and show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each of which is characterized by a unique pattern of temporal fluctuations in functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) signal. This hypothesis has been tested using fMRI, but the results have been inconsistent. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to directly measure the organization of the brain’s total activity, and we found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired during rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain’s total activity, and its potential functional significance.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD+ RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD+ RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery has important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. (Show more)

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The epigenetic changes at these loci are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The findings also suggest that epigenetic alterations at these loci may be a target for the development of new therapies for diabetes. This study provides a unique resource for future studies on the role of epigenetic alterations in the pathogenesis of diabetes complications. (Show more)

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of targeted therapy has led to poor prognosis. We show that the expression of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is up-regulated in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which contribute to the overall aroma and flavor. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not well understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changes in response to temperature, with the number of species required to maintain ecosystem functioning increasing as temperatures rise. This result is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species, which determine the likelihood that more species will be present in a community at high and low temperatures. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined impacts of global warming and biodiversity loss, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance curves of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional architecture is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for place-cell encoding, are strongly clustered anatomically, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells are less clustered and tend to intermingle. These data suggest that grid cells might form a largely distinct network from those of other cell types, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the topographic organization of neurons in MEC and their functional coupling, which will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for the flowering of both host and parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized type of nigral neuron that forms a bouquet-like arborization that targets the dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent cell bodies. This is the first demonstration of a striatonigral loop, which is likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study also demonstrates the utility of expansion microscopy for the study of the nigrostriatal system. (Show more)

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the heart rate in the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the generation of the heart rate. We also show that STIM1 regulates the heart rate by controlling the content of the calcium stores in SANCs. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provide a molecular mechanism for the regulation of heart rate. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of silicon in plant growth and stress tolerance and may lead to the development of new strategies for the management of insect pests. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system, which is involved in many physiological and pathological processes. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still not fully understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. Our results reveal a new role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity may be a promising strategy for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-loaded DNA nanostructures determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. (Show more)

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that supports a large fraction of the world’s population and is a major source of ecosystem services. However, the coastal zone is also a major source of nutrient pollution, which can fuel harmful algal blooms and other ecological and human health problems. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of coastal nutrient pollution, and that their importance may be underestimated. Our findings suggest that efforts to reduce coastal nutrient pollution should focus on small tributaries, which can be a major source of nutrients in many coastal areas.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal fluctuation” phenomenon in statistical physics, where the rare events that are most likely to occur are those that extremize the environment’s response to the system. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems and for the design of optimal thermodynamic machines.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which can then predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same circuit parameters that are tolerated in the control condition may be critical to the control of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may be a promising avenue for future treatment strategies.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying the magnitude of these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia. This study provides a key example of how we can use a combination of proxies and modeling to understand the history of abrupt climate change. This approach can be applied to other abrupt climate change events to further our understanding of the history of abrupt climate change.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and other organelles. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of this process, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal life, and the genetic basis of sex is a major area of study. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular system of sexual polymorphism, where the same trait can vary in expression between sexes and between sexes and the environment. This modular system of sexual polymorphism provides a context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE, respectively. The RPE is also challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that is formed by the oxidation of the vitamin A aldehyde, A2E. We show that the levels of iron (Fe) in the retina impact the formation of the yellow pigment, lipofuscin. We also show that the levels of Fe impact the oxidation and degradation of the photoreceptor-derived A2E. These findings have important implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve specialization on different prey types, and that the evolution of their tentacles is linked to prey type. Our findings help understand the evolution of specialization in predators, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure, and the evolution of the modern human hand is a major focus of hominin research. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. The fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of this feature, which is present in modern humans and Neandertals but not in early hominins. The fossil also suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) provides these units, but cancer cells have a deficiency in the uptake of the glycine required for SHMT enzymatic activity. We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in cancer cells. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the cytotoxicity of the inhibitor in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of this cancer type. These findings provide a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that natural landscapes such as forests can contribute to meeting both food and nutrition security goals. We found that deforestation over a 5-y period (2008–2013) led to a reduction in household fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation over the survey period led to an increase in consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. We hope that this study will encourage further research on the role of natural landscapes in meeting food and nutrition security goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods on Earth has had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
